text: What's up, outliers? Quick market update, bit of a day out there. We don't have a live stream today. We're running a new cadence. The live streams will be Tuesday and Thursday. So we'll run a couple of these market updates in the meantime to tie this over. So what happened today? Pretty big market reversal. The market was down a pretty solid portion of the day and then towards the tail. And it started to rotate back over. So we take a look at futures here. This is just the micro Eminis. You can see that through most of last week started off down, open up today, 13th. And we opened up really soft and we were rolling down through this. And then we got bid back up. That was very curious to me. So if we grab SPX instead, which will have a little bit more follow through, you'll notice the size of the candles here is very different issues because there's more transactions going on in here in the index itself via options and whatnot. So I mean, this is still objectively a lower low, even though it didn't fall out of bed here. I don't think we're out of the woods. This still looks like the level to be beat the downside. text: the total market components. So the market is still rotating over. That's what this tells me. It's too early to call it heads or tails in either way, but I do think having some sort of long inverse deltas is probably not off the table. So when I say long inverse deltas, it's essentially beta weighted deltas that are negative that were long. And the reason why I say long is just because it controls risk a little bit more than being overall short options into that. So the easier way to think of it is just being short beta weighted deltas, but using some sort of long premium strategy. That is essentially what we're seeing across the market today. Now from an economics perspective, we had a few things come out that were absolutely important. So CPI came in light. It was expected at 5.3 came in at 5.22, which is not actually super great. Inflation expectations came in pretty close to expectations. And then CPI, we have to take a look at year-to-year and month-over-month. So we'll jump on that in a second. So one of the things I really like to do is track this because you can see that near term changes and expectations happening real time in other levels of expectation.
